head.supplied: 10/6/69. ¶ ¶ I am glad to announce, dear Mr Guilfoyle, that the highly valuable case full of plants, presented by your worthy father and yourself, and gathered in your rambles over the pacific groups...

div.p: RB MSS 439c, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne.

I am glad to announce, dear Mr Guilfoyle, that the highly valuable case full of plants, presented by your worthy father and yourself, and gathered in your rambles over the pacific groups, have quite uninjured arrived, except one plant, which by breakage is hopelessly destroyed. Let me thank you not only for this valuable present, but also for the friendly feelings, which you evince on this occasion again towards me. I will gladly examine all the Dracaenas or Cordylines (as the case may be) whenever the promised flowering portions of the respective plants arrive. I have some few years ago worked up all the Australian species, so that these now will be doubly interesting to me. If you have seeds left (or rather berries) of any, they will aid me much in drawing up the diagnosis.

For New Caledonian plants it is here far too cold, as we are several degrees further south then
sic.
Sydney & moreover exposed to the piercing antartic breezes. I will however put your New Caledonians into my greenhouses, where already a group of plants from that island exists. If the Nephralipis should turn out new I will gladly adopt your name for it & give you the diagnosis for publication.
did this happen?
I suppose the Sydney philos. Society publishes papers regularly , into which such notes could be inserted. Our good & learned friend Mr Woolls shall also be duely honored as you very rightly suggested.

div.p: Grow any Lemnas in your ponds wild at Double Bay
